text: [Music]
hi everyone I am Niharika back with a
new lesson for you today we are going to
look at some sports related business
idioms now when you do business with
native English speakers you will come
across a lot of expressions related to
war fire held and so on but the biggest
area belongs to sports so I have some
expressions for you that are related to
sports and these expressions will help
you to speak fluently in the business
world so let's have a look the first one
that I have for you is kickoff but of
course kickoff comes from the game
football and what does it mean well
especially when players begin the game
of football the first thing is the
kickoff that's when the game starts
right now
here also the expression kickoff means
to begin something to start something so
for example if you have to use it while
speaking then you would say that good
morning everyone
so should we kick off the meeting so
this means that should we start the
meeting the kickoff means to start
something alright the second expression
that I have for you is on target now on
target belongs to the game of archery
and what does it mean well on target
means that you are making a good
progress and you're likely to achieve
your goals
so if you have to use it in a sentence
you would say well apparently we all are
on target and we might definitely get
this project so this means that whatever
you're doing or planning to win a
contract or to win a project you are on
target so you're making progress and you
are running towards achieving the goal
okay
so that's what on target means to make
progress and therefore you're likely to
achieve your goals
the third one that I have for you is up
to scratch now up to scratch belongs to
the game of track and field
and what does this mean when we use this
expression in the business world well up
to scratch means to be of a good
standard or to be acceptable now this
means that when we work in a team
probably we need people in our team who
are good in their work who are of a good
standard right so that's why we use the
expression up to scratch for example you
can say that well this project is very
very important for us and the people
that we hire for this project should be
up to scratch this means they should be
off good standards ok so that's when you
can use this expression the next one
that I have for you is know the ropes
now know the ropes well it comes from
sailing belongs to the world of sailing
and what does it mean well know the
ropes means someone who really has all
the knowledge and skills to do or to
perform certain work so when you hire
someone you hire a new team member or
you hire a new director and you say that
he really knows the ropes so this means
that he does have all the knowledge and
the skills to perform in a great
excellent manner ok so that's when you
use the phrase know the ropes the next
one that I have for you is ballpark
figure a ballpark figure belongs to the
game of baseball and the meaning of
ballpark figure is a rough estimate
so when we use or how do we use in the
business world well you might have heard
people saying could you give me a
ballpark figure of the sales this year
or could you give me a ballpark figure
that we need to pay for this project
okay or the costings so here you are
asking for a rough estimate or a
guesstimate okay so you are asking for a
very rough estimate and that's what you
mean when you use the expression
ballpark figure
okay the next one that I have for you is
jump the gun now what does this really
mean well it comes
um well the origin of this expression is
you know when at leats
they are ready to race okay they always
start their race on hearing the pistol
okay but at times when athletes they
just begin racing they just start
running even before hearing the pistol
fire this means that they jumped the gun
and probably they are disqualified or
they start the game again so jump the
gun means when you just take the next
step forward even before thinking what
would be the consequences okay so maybe
you're going too fast so if you want to
use this expression in the business
world you would say I don't want to jump
the gun with this presentation so here
what I mean is probably this
presentation is extremely important it's
essential to get a contract to get a
project and I really don't want to jump
the gun I really don't want to go very
fast I want to go ahead and you know
research on this and you know prepare
myself really well for this presentation
so you don't want to go too
without thinking okay so that's when you
would use this expression the next one
that I have for you is in pole position
this belongs to car racing and in pole
position means you know when a car when
when the cars are ready to race okay
pole position is considered to be the
best position for the car to begin the
race very lucky ones get that so the
pole position is the best position and
when we talk about in pole position four
or eight for the business world it means
that you are doing good you are in a
good position to achieve something so
this means that probably our company is
in pole position to win this contract so
this means that we have a great chance
of winning this contract
okay so means we are in a great position
right and then the last one that I have
for you is neck-and-neck belongs to
horse racing
now neck-and-neck is a very very tough
competition Baron for example in a horse
race okay let's consider the example of
a horse race so probably they are just
about to end the race and it's a very
tough competition because both are
really doing well okay both the jockeys
are riding really fast and the
difference is just gonna be very little
okay anyone can win either it can be a
or it can be it can be be anybody can
win so it's a very neck-and-neck
competition so here when we use it in
the business world again neck-and-neck
means a great competition veteran
anybody can achieve or win a project of
contract okay for example um
we are neck-and-neck with the
competitors so we have to really work
hard in order to achieve this contract
okay so which means that even a
competitor's are doing extremely well
and there are chances that they may also
get the contract but we have to work
really hard with our neck-and-neck
competitors
okay so this is the way you would use
these expressions and start using them
on daily basis in order to sound really
fluent specially in the business world
I'll be back with a new lesson for you
